Unread mail dashboard using gscript and streamlit # The idea to create email dashboard is to showcase
How many new emails came in every day This daily number gives me if i have oversubscibed to some unnecessary mailers by virtu of signing up for the sake of trying the this also tells me ho many emails i read day wise But this is not the actual idea at all # The real reason behind this project is to try out streamlit and create a live dashboard of sorts.
Conneting to my gmail just gives me the real data that is getting generated daily on its own.
Gmail integration and data gathering # 11th Feb 2026: Inside a google sheet i created a simple google app script to fetch my unread emails from gmail. Gmail allows only 500 emails to be read at once, and i had near about unread emails. after fetching emails i would write counts of how many emails came in per day but when i tested the count written by acript and actual count was a mismatch. when i investigated the initial or last few emails were missing (i had log the subject that it counted for that particular day).upon further investigation i found out that it was taking server date time that is available to see when i open the view original message. Also that time was in PST format, this time was little different from the actual time shown because it was not off by any factor of 30 minutes. The actual time that we see on the email is actually inside the email body and string paring using reex need to written for it. after trying for 20 times gemini was not able to write code for it and i had to switch new chat and give very short instructions to achieve the time extraction. once this was done i was easily able to get what i wanted and it matched the count.
so finally i logged all the emails, i also made sure on reruns it checks and skips already logged unread emails. inlogged unique thread id.time received, subject, email link and a checkbox.
after that i asked Gemini to extend the code to read the email unique ids from sheet and if any email is now read mark the check box to mark it as read and in another column log today’s date.
Free of cost server setup # 12th Feb 2026
I had found about about Oracle free perpetual server offering, so i wanted had already signed up for it earlier. now i set up a streamlit environment and github codespace linked to a github repo for this project. Now i can continue to work on this from any browser.
summary: i have got lot of emails pending on gmail and i want to know how many emails are coming every day and how many i am reading
title: Unread mail dashboard using gscript and streamlit

Generate QR Codes in Google Sheets Using External URLs # I’ll show how to generate QR codes directly inside Google Sheets using external URLs. This method does not require Google Apps Script, add-ons, or any complex setup.
It is quick, practical, and works well for most basic use cases.
Basic QR Code Formula # Google Sheets supports the IMAGE() function, which allows images to be rendered inside cells.
=IMAGE( "https://api.qrserver.com/v1/create-qr-code/?size=200x200&data=" & ENCODEURL(A1) ) How it works # A1 contains the text or URL ENCODEURL() safely handles special characters The external service generates the QR image IMAGE() displays it directly in the cell Whenever the value in A1 changes, the QR code updates automatically.
Alternate QR Code URLs You Can Use # 1. QRServer (Recommended) # https://api.qrserver.com/v1/create-qr-code/?size=200x200&data= Example:
=IMAGE("https://api.qrserver.com/v1/create-qr-code/?size=200x200&data=" & ENCODEURL(A1)) Pros
Free No API key required Stable and widely used 2. QuickChart # https://quickchart.io/qr?size=200&text= Example:
=IMAGE("https://quickchart.io/qr?size=200&text=" & ENCODEURL(A1)) Pros
Actively maintained Clean QR output 3. Image-Charts # https://image-charts.com/chart?chs=150x150&cht=qr&chl= Example:
=IMAGE("https://image-charts.com/chart?chs=150x150&cht=qr&chl=" & ENCODEURL(A1)) Pros
Actively maintained Works with Google Sheets IMAGE() function Simple URL-based integration When This Approach Makes Sense # This method is ideal when:
You want instant QR codes You are already working in Google Sheets You need bulk QR generation You want zero scripting Closing Note # This is one of the simplest ways to generate QR codes using Google Sheets.
In future posts, this can be extended using Google Apps Script for automation and advanced workflows.
summary: A beginner-friendly guide to creating QR codes in Google Sheets using external QR APIs. Simple formulas, alternate services, and zero scripting.
title: Generate QR Codes in Google Sheets
